prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for getting really mad at my boyfriend when he said all girls who game are bad?
We were playing together and one of our teammates was doing stuff that was a bit questionable. 
My boyfriend noticed that the username of the player was girly and started talking about how bad girls are in video games and kept referring to girls as bitches. I got frustrated by it and asked if he thought I was bad too since I happen to be a girl and he replied that I would be if I didn't have him.

I decided to just stop playing after that match. We texted a bit back and forth about this, he said I was a whiny bitch. He also said I was no longer a female in the wild so I wasn't that bad.
He complained that I took offense when he didn't say anything offensive.
I told him it was really uncalled for and that he can't look at one girl playing and say that all girls are bad, we have run into so many "bad" players that were guys and he said nothing about it.

I don't know if I overreacted about it, I got mad and I did call him a dick two or three times. I told him to not play with me if I'm so bad and that he definitely has some sexism in him. I didn't really get to say much else as he was ranting on about how girls don't have hunting instinct like guys. 
He has taught me stuff in games that he played before I started, that I won't deny and I've been thankful for it. I just really disagree with what he is saying and I don't think it's weird that I took offense.
What do you guys think, did I overreact? 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out whether the author is in the wrong here. So the situation is that the boyfriend made a sexist comment about all girls being bad at gaming, using a teammate's girly username as an example. The author got mad and confronted him, leading to an argument. The boyfriend then called her a "whiny bitch" and other things, and the author called him a dick a few times. The author is questioning if she overreacted.

First, I need to assess if the boyfriend's comments were offensive. He generalized all female gamers as bad and used derogatory language ("bitches"). That's clearly sexist and disrespectful. The author, as a female gamer, feeling offended by that makes sense. She challenged him by asking if he thought she was bad, and his response was dismissive. His follow-up comments about her not being a "female in the wild" are also problematic, implying that she's an exception, which is still sexist.

The boyfriend's argument is that he didn't say anything offensive. But making a generalization based on gender is inherently offensive. The author's reaction—getting angry and stopping the game—is a reasonable response to being insulted. Calling him a "dick" is a mild reaction compared to the harmful nature of his comments.

The boyfriend's continued rant about hunting instincts and other sexist remarks show that he's not open to the discussion. The author is standing up for herself against his sexism, which is valid. Even though there's a history of him helping her with gaming, that doesn't excuse his comments. The key issue here is the sexism, which the author is rightly addressing.

So, considering all that, the author is not in the wrong. Her reaction is justified, and the boyfriend's comments are the real issue here. The answer should be B.
